ScenarioEntry.name: Action Incomplete
ScenarioEntry.Description: User has not even started doing the right action

MessageEntry.Message: You are correct to evaluate <feature>, however <concept> is not the right value. It seems that <feature> was not properly <action> on the slide to evaluate it.
Remove <concept> from your report and make sure that <feature> is properly <action> on the slide before evaluating it.

ScenarioEntry.name: Measure HPF Done
ScenarioEntry.Description: user has measured high power fields

MessageEntry.Message: You seem to have observed ten distinct high powered fields. This should allow you to determine <feature>.
You seem to have observed ten distinct high powered fields. This should allow you to determine <feature>.

ScenarioEntry.name: Measure MM2 Done
ScenarioEntry.Description: user measured mm2

MessageEntry.Message: You seem to have observed an area equivalent to a square millimeter at high power. This should allow you to determine <feature>.
You seem to have observed an area equivalent to a square millimeter at high power. This should allow you to determine <feature>.

ScenarioEntry.name: Measure Ruler Done
ScenarioEntry.Description: positive feedback on correct measurement

MessageEntry.Message: You seem to have correctly measured <feature> at the same location as our expert pathologist. You should now be able to properly evaluate it.
You seem to have correctly measured <feature> at the same location as our expert pathologist. You should now be able to properly evaluate it.

ScenarioEntry.name: Measure Ruler Incorrect Angle
ScenarioEntry.Description: measuring in not optimal location

MessageEntry.Message: You are in the right area to measure <feature>, however you ruler is not at the proper angle to measure <feature> correctly.
<definition>
This is where <feature> was <action> by our expert pathologist.

ScenarioEntry.name: Measure Ruler Incorrect Location
ScenarioEntry.Description: measuring in incorrect location

MessageEntry.Message: You don't seem to be measuring in correct location.
It looks like <feature> is the nearest feature that can be <action>.
<definition>
This is the lesion that you want to measure. Try to find the best location to measure it.
This is where <feature> was <action> by our expert pathologist.

ScenarioEntry.name: Measure Ruler Incorrect Size
ScenarioEntry.Description: measuring within the recommended area but underestimating the span of the micrometer (inside the rectangle but not crossing the borders)

MessageEntry.Message: The correct area is being measured, but the end points of the micrometer are not positioned correctly, so you are not estimating the <feature> correctly.
<definition>
This is where <feature> was <action> by our expert pathologist.

ScenarioEntry.name: Observe All Done
ScenarioEntry.Description: positive feeback on margin measurement

MessageEntry.Message: You seem to have looked at all necessary <defined_feature>. This should allow you to determine their status.
You seem to have looked at all necessary <defined_feature>. This should allow you to determine their status.

ScenarioEntry.name: Attribute Negation is Incorrect
ScenarioEntry.Description: You have implied finding as absent, when it is not

MessageEntry.Message: You have stated that there is NO <concept> in you report. Actually, <concept> is present in this case, and is an important prognostic factor to report
Actually, <concept> is an important prognostic feature that is present in this case and should be reported on.
You can generally observe <concept> here.
This is an example of <concept>.
Remove the negation of <concept> from your report.

ScenarioEntry.name: Attribute Not Valid
ScenarioEntry.Description: Attribute is not valid. That is there is no such finding that includes it: Ex: moderate blister

MessageEntry.Message: In the context of this domain, <concept> is not a valid qualifier of <feature>.
Remove <concept> quality from the description of <feature>.

ScenarioEntry.name: Attribute Numeric Value is Incorrect
ScenarioEntry.Description: Incorrect numeric attribute was given

MessageEntry.Message: You are correct to evaluate <feature>, however <value> is not a correct value. Perhaps you have not <action> it correctly.
The correct value is <correct_value>

ScenarioEntry.name: Attribute Set Not Valid
ScenarioEntry.Description: No finding exists that includes the given set of attribute values. It may be valid attribute if put in as a separate finding Ex: [subepidermal blister, intraepidermal] VS [subepidremal blister] and [inraepidermal blister] concept

MessageEntry.Message: In the context of this domain, <concept> in conjunction with <finding> is not a valid finding that is understood by the system. However it may be a valid evidence if it is asserted along with another instance of <feature>.
Remove <concept> quality from the description of <feature>.
You may also try to assert another instance of <feature> qualified with <concept> attribute.

ScenarioEntry.name: Attribute Value is Incorrect
ScenarioEntry.Description: Attribute value is incorrect, but the user is on the right track. Ex: user picks incorrect QUANTITY.

MessageEntry.Message: You are correct to mention <attribute> of <feature>, however <concept> is not the best way to describe <attribute> in this case.
Remove <concept> from the description of <feature>, and assert correct <attribute>.

ScenarioEntry.name: Attribute is Incorrect
ScenarioEntry.Description: The modifier is not the correct way to specify a feature in this case

MessageEntry.Message: In the context of this case, <concept> is not the best way to describe <feature>
Remove <concept> as the description of <feature>.

ScenarioEntry.name: Attribute is Not Important
ScenarioEntry.Description: The user was more specific then is required by case Ex: subepidermal blister is required by case, but user puts in subepidermal blister extend beyound ...

MessageEntry.Message: While <concept> might be an important quality of <feature> in a different context, it is unnecessary in this case.

ScenarioEntry.name: Diagnosis Not Specific Enough
ScenarioEntry.Description: Diagnosis is on the right path, but has not reached the right DX yet.

MessageEntry.Message: You are correct, this is a case of <concept>. However you should specify it further to make it a more meaningful diagnosis.
You are correct, this is a case of <concept>. However you should specify it further to make it a more meaningful diagnosis.
Diagnosie that are more specific then <concept> are: <potential_diagnoses>.
<diagnosis> is the correct diagnosis for this case.

ScenarioEntry.name: Diagnosis is Incorrect
ScenarioEntry.Description: Diagnosis is not correct diagnosis nor is on the path to it

MessageEntry.Message: <concept> is not a correct diagnosis for this case.
<concept> is not a correct diagnosis for this case.
You should remove <concept> and try to come up with the correct diagnoses.

ScenarioEntry.name: Diagnosis is Too General
ScenarioEntry.Description: Dx class is on the trunk Dx tree right before divergence

MessageEntry.Message: The diagnosis <concept> is too general to be useful.
Remove <concept> or specify it further to make it a meaningful diagnosis.

ScenarioEntry.name: Diagnosis is Too Specific
ScenarioEntry.Description: Dx is more specific the required

MessageEntry.Message: The diagnosis <concept> is correct, however it is more specific than the evidence suggests in this case.
The diagnosis <concept> is correct, however it is more specific than the evidence suggests in this case.

ScenarioEntry.name: Case Not Solved
ScenarioEntry.Description: Case has not been solved yet

MessageEntry.Message: The case report is not complete yet, You need to address all of the outstanding issues as well as put all relevant reportable findings that are required by a reporting template.

ScenarioEntry.name: Finding Not in Case
ScenarioEntry.Description: This finding is not mentioned in the case

MessageEntry.Message: In the context of this domain and case, <concept> is not something that was mentined by the expert in this case nor listed as necessary prognostic factor in the reporting template
In the context of this domain and case, <concept> is not something that was mentined by the expert in this case nor listed as necessary prognostic factor in the reporting template

ScenarioEntry.name: Finding is Incorrect
ScenarioEntry.Description: The finding belongs to a template that should be mentioned in the report yet is incorrect value

MessageEntry.Message: You are correct to talk about <template>, however <concept> is not the right <template> in this case.
Remove <concept> from your report

ScenarioEntry.name: Finding is Too General
ScenarioEntry.Description: Finding is too general to be meaningful

MessageEntry.Message: You are on the right track, however finding <concept> is too general to be a meaningful prognostic factor.
You are correct that <concept> should be mentioned in the report, however it must be specified further to make it a more meaningful prognostic factor.
Some possibilities are: <children> .
In the context of this case <finding> is the best way to describe this feature.

ScenarioEntry.name: Case Solved
ScenarioEntry.Description: all features are listed, press SUBMIT

MessageEntry.Message: You've listed all important prognostic features. Press Check Report button to check if you are done with the report. Then go to Finish Case tab to proceed to the next problem.

ScenarioEntry.name: Missing Action
ScenarioEntry.Description: need to accomplish actions before

MessageEntry.Message: You are correct to mention <concept> in your report. However to make it a meaningful prognostic factor, you need to measure it in order to report on its value.
<definition>
This is an area where <concept> can be <action>. It should be <action> using at least <power> power.
This is a part of the slide where <concept> can be <action> particularly well.

ScenarioEntry.name: Missing Attribute
ScenarioEntry.Description: need to specify further

MessageEntry.Message: You are correct to mention <defined_feature> in your report. However, you need to report on its <attribute> to make it a meaningful prognostic factor.
Some possible values that <defined_feature> can take are: <attribute_values> .
In the context of this case, <finding> is the best way to describe this feature.

ScenarioEntry.name: Missing Defining Attribute
ScenarioEntry.Description: There are several findings that match that feature, so need to specify the attribute that can distinguish them.

MessageEntry.Message: There are several instances of <feature> that should be mentioned in your report. You need to specify which <feature> you are talking about by adding additional qualities.
You need to specify which <feature> you are talking about by adding one of the following qualities: <defining_attributes>.
You can add <defined_feature> to your report as one possibility.

ScenarioEntry.name: Missing Diagnosis
ScenarioEntry.Description: You need to specify a diagnosis

MessageEntry.Message: All medical reports must have a final diagnosis listed. You need to state a final diagnosis in your report.

There are important visual cues that you should look for on the digital slide to come up with the final diagnosis. If you are unsure what the diagnosis is, you should try solving this case in the diagnostic tutor. Click here to do that.
If you look at the digital slide carefuly, you can see a number of features: <findings>. What diagnosis has these features?
<concept> has all of the expected features. This would be a reasonable diagnosis in this case.

ScenarioEntry.name: Missing Finding
ScenarioEntry.Description: more features needs to be identified it has not been observed

MessageEntry.Message: There's something important to recognize here.
This is an area where you should be able to evaluate [1]
This is an example where <feature> can be <action> particularly well.
You should mention <feature> in your report.

ScenarioEntry.name: Missing HPF Action
ScenarioEntry.Description: Need to do an HPF measurement

MessageEntry.Message: In oder to correctly evaluate <feature>, it should be properly <action> first.
<definition>
Here is an area where you need to observe 10 non overlapping high power fields at maxium zoom level.
Here is an example of what you should be counting while looking at the slide at high power.

ScenarioEntry.name: Missing Header
ScenarioEntry.Description: You are missing report header: Ex: tissue, location, procedure

MessageEntry.Message: It is common practice to start all reports with a line indicating tissue type, tissue location, and the procedure that was used.
You are missing <template> from your report. What is the <template>?
<concept> is the correct <template> that is missing from your report.

ScenarioEntry.name: Missing MM2 Action
ScenarioEntry.Description: Use haven't covered mm^2 at sufficient power

MessageEntry.Message: In oder to correctly evaluate <feature>, it should be properly <action> first.
<definition>
Here is a location where you need to observe an a area, that is equivalent to a square millimeter, at high power (maximum zoom level) .
Here is an example of what you should be counting while exploring the area at high power.

ScenarioEntry.name: Missing Modifier
ScenarioEntry.Description: Missing a modifier

MessageEntry.Message: You are correct to mention <defined_feature> in your report. However you should specify it further to make it a meaningful prognostic factor.
To further specify <defined_feature> you need to add qualities to it. Some possible qualities are: <potential_attributes> .
In the context of this case <finding> is the best way to describe this feature.

ScenarioEntry.name: Missing Negation
ScenarioEntry.Description: You have not mentioned that the finding is absent

MessageEntry.Message: You incorrectly implied the presence of <concept>, in this case, <concept> is absent and should be stated as such.
Please state that there is <finding> in your report.

ScenarioEntry.name: Missing Observe All Action
ScenarioEntry.Description: need to observe all regions of a given feature

MessageEntry.Message: In oder to correctly evaluate <defined_feature>, it should be properly <action> first.
Here is a location where you can observe <feature>. You need to observe all such regions at <power> power to correctly evaluate <feature>.
Here is another region that has not been observed yet.

ScenarioEntry.name: Missing Ruler Action
ScenarioEntry.Description: Need to measure with ruler

MessageEntry.Message: In oder to correctly evaluate <feature>, it should be properly <action> first.
<definition>
This is the lesion that you want to measure. Try to find the best location to measure it.
This is where <feature> was <action> by our expert pathologist.

ScenarioEntry.name: Missing Similar Finding
ScenarioEntry.Description: similar finding has been mentioned already

MessageEntry.Message: You already mentioned <sibling>, there is another type of <feature> that you should mention in your report.
<defined_feature> needs to be added to your report

ScenarioEntry.name: Missing Value
ScenarioEntry.Description: Finding is mssing a numeric or some other calculable value

MessageEntry.Message: You are correct to mention [1] in your report. However, to make it a meaningful prognostic factor, you need to report on its value.
It looks like <concept> has already been <action> on the slide. You should be able to determine the value.
The correct value is <value>, so you should put <finding> in your report.

ScenarioEntry.name: Missing Worksheet
ScenarioEntry.Description: This is hints for worksheet elements, s.a. TNM Staging

MessageEntry.Message: Your report is missing Pathological Staging (pTNM)
All melanoma reports should contain Pathological Staging (pTNM). You can use Tumor Staging Worksheet button to insert relevant pTNM stage into your report or type it in by hand.
Your report is missing <template> stage. What is it?
Correct

ScenarioEntry.name: Nothing is Done Yet
ScenarioEntry.Description: Nothing has been done yet

MessageEntry.Message: You should explore the slide, come up with the diagnosis, and identify all relevant prognostic factors that you think are relevant to the final diagnosis. Type your report into the provided text area.

ScenarioEntry.name: No Such Concept in Domain
ScenarioEntry.Description: This normally doesn't happen, but this state is generated when a user concept doesn't exist in the domain

MessageEntry.Message: <concept> does not exist in the domain

ScenarioEntry.name: Removed Correct Concept
ScenarioEntry.Description: This is a state that has no messages and corresponds to removing a correct concept.
